newsitem.title: FRANCE: French writer opposes euro on linguistic grounds.
newsitem.headline: French writer opposes euro on linguistic grounds.

text.p: A French writer put forward a new argument on Monday for renegotiating Europe's planned single currency: he said "euro" is a meaningless word that has no plural.

As European Union leaders met in Amsterdam to tackle differences over the currency, Maurice Druon, life secretary of the prestigious French Academy, said the euro "is only the abbreviation of a word that does not exist".

Nor does it have a plural, as each country will have to invent its own, Druon, chief guardian of the French language, wrote in the daily Le Figaro. The fact it would be divided into 100 "cents", like the dollar, was a recipe for confusion.

Druon suggested calling the European currency the "as", after the earliest Roman money. "'As' is a word that can be pronounced in all our languages, and its division is easy: the 'centias'," Druon said.
"A decision as important as the name of the currency that will be used by more than 250 million people cannot be taken lightly."
